body:
this solution found here: [https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/issues/4833](https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/issues/4833) worked for me finally,
```
{
    name: 'status',
    type: 'enum',
    enum: ['active', 'inactive', 'paused'],
    enumName: 'statusEnum',
    default: '"inactive"'
}
```

This happens with PostgreSQL as well.
Following is the result of TypeOrm field definition:
```sql
"status" "status_enum" DEFAULT \'null\'
```
From:
```typescript
@Column({ name: "status", type: "enum", enum: Status, nullable: true, default: null })
public status: Status| null = null;
```
Resulting in:

> 'invalid input value for enum status_enum: "null"'

Probably due to putting null inside `''` and escaping it.

Suggested answer by @robertrypula just removes the default value since by setting the property to `undefined` we are telling TypeOrm that there is no default value for this field. This is not a workaround; it is just a way to ignore the bug.

The same fix when applied here should fix the problem with PostgreSQL:

https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/blob/master/src/driver/postgres/PostgresDriver.ts#L724

issue.title: Nullable default value for `Enum` types

repository.name: typeorm
repository.description: ORM for TypeScript and JavaScript. Supports MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, SQLite, MS SQL Server, Oracle, SAP Hana, WebSQL databases. Works in NodeJS, Browser, Ionic, Cordova and Electron platforms.

issue.body:
### Description of change
This PR is the result of a conversation at #5371 regarding a bug with TypeOrm and MySQL resulting in the generation of an invalid table create query for enum fields with a default value of `null`
This happens simply due to treating `null` as another value for the enum and therefore, escaping and passing it as a string to the database.
The fix was easy, we are already checking for `undefined` before searching in enum and escaping the value in case there was no default value specified, now we are also checking for `null` in case the passed default value is _special_ and should not be treated like others.
This is done by simply replacing `value !== undefined` with `value != null` therefore checking for both conditions.

### Pull-Request Checklist

- [X] Code is up-to-date with the `master` branch
- [ ] `npm run lint` passes with this change
- [ ] `npm run test` passes with this change
- [X] This pull request links relevant issues as `Fixes #0000`
- [ ] There are new or updated unit tests validating the change
- [ ] Documentation has been updated to reflect this change
- [ ] The new commits follow conventions explained in [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)

This is a small change and so I did the changes on my browser without setting up the project for test, build, and lint. But honestly, I don't think it can break anything! Feel free to reject it if it doesn't fits the standards!

Thank you for the great library.

body: what is the point to set `default: null`, if when you set `nullable: true` database already sets you a null by default?
It is probably unnecessary if the database uses null by default, but likely the user is just trying to be explicit with the default value and there shouldn't be unexpected behavior like this.

issue.title: fix: fixed all known enum issues
